Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I don't want to give a lazy "it depends" answer, but there is no hard-and-fast rule.  With networks, companies tend to invest in them or not invest in them.  In terms of readiness, you're basically looking to avoid a situation in which a company has big, flat, unmanaged network with no technical expertise available to do things you may need done (e.g., whitelist ports, setup VLANs).  The approach required for a small office network is completely different to that of a plant with hundreds or thousands of devices.  If it's completely brand new territory, it may not be bad idea to get consult with a local network engineer on a few projects.  Reach out to a partner of one of the large networking tech companies.

If you'd like to be thorough, read up on the Industrial Control System (ICS) reference architectures prescribed by NIST and the major network vendors (e.g., Cisco, Palo Alto Networks).  Because some of the vendor-specific reference architectures push their own solutions, read them with a "grain of salt".  Focus on understanding the concepts and themes (e.g., redundancy, topology, minimize broadcast domains, segmentation, determinism, QoS, NAT, access policies).  

Also, as a side note, you will likely encounter a lot of the "Purdue" security model in these architecture.  This prescribes DMZ'ing each level of ISA95.  Many in this community, for good reasons, are critical of this approach.  It can unwieldy in UNS and more contemporary IIoT architectures.  But, in basically every project, there will be a ton of unsecure devices with unsecure networks.  There has to be special consideration for this.  While MQTT is an "outbound" protocol with transport security, it's not a "silver bullet" for security.  Not every device has MQTT and not every device has a dedicated interface for it.  That same interface may be shared with a native protocol, fieldbus, http, ssh, etc to support other features.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I‚Äôll usually plan on a /24 for each unique machine or operation in a cell/line.

Five identical CNCs fed by a gantry robot? They go into a /24 for the whole op.

Four very different operations (broach, wash, drill, balance) fed by two robots? And each asset has its own field network of I/O, motion, safety, etc? Too much complexity and too much complexity if something needs to change. Each asset will get its own /24. Asset-to-asset fieldbus communications will  get routed.

For the last octet, I‚Äôll reserve the first 10 for gateways (typically only need one). For the rest, every block of twenty represents a different device type (e.g., 11-30 PLC, 31-40 HMI).

10.1[cell/line no].[op no].[device type and instance].

Normally, this is kind of cumbersome to setup any other network like this, but industrial nodes are very simple. They don‚Äôt do much more than IPv4. DNS is not consistently available or implemented. There isn‚Äôt as much network orchestration magic that can utilized.

Also, as MRIIOT mentioned, consistency is key. When the setup is consistent and there is no overlap, the less people have to think about routing or nat‚Äôing or any complexity. It just works. It also makes segmentation and troubleshooting much easier.

Author: siraj4974
Content: Is there any difference between the #Cisco IE 3000 line & the Rockwell #Stratix 8000 series? We are going to use them for networking purposes within the plant, not for any other purpose. Looking for some light on this topic.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The difference between these two product series is generally the firmware. 

The Rockwell version will have their browser-based config GUI. This version can also can exposed as a CIP endpoint to be managed over the EtherNet/IP fieldbus like one would with, say, a drive. This allows the switch to be configured with an AOI/AOP within Studio 5000. So, basically, a ControlLogix or CompactLogix could control the switch. Personally, I find this use case somewhat unusual. I have not played around with it or encountered it. Perhaps it‚Äôs for monitoring diagnostics if there is not something like SNMP in use.

The Cisco versions will be managed through IOS/IOS-XE. If I recall, some versions of the Cisco have a GUI. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if the GUIs are similar or the same.

In either case, I‚Äôve seen scenarios where IOS and TFTP were required for provisioning. There are some limitations in the GUI for some functionality (e.g., some L3 features and routing) and they can be sluggish.

In the typical automation network, it‚Äôs the same product.

Author: karltbraun
Content: Not sure if the Rockwell version is Cybervision compatible; we're planning on using that to allow more integration between IT and OT while providing necessary security by using Cisco's security line to baseline normal activity and alert (by exception!) on abnormal activity.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's a reference architecture:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/se/internet-of-things/datasheet-c78-743222.html

For in-panel (IP20) switching, the Cybervision reference architecture includes the Cisco IE3300 and IE3400 series.  The Rockwell equivalent of this is the Stratix 5800 series.  These have more in common with the current generation Catalyst 9300/9400 feature set.  These have the newer IOS (i.e., IOS-XE) and software-defined networking (i.e., DNA) features.

If would recommend looking into the protocol dependencies of Cybersion (e.g., SNMP, Netflow, SPAN).  This will ultimately determine what products and firmware levels are compatible.

At the end of the day, the Rockwell versions run the same "Catalyst" hardware and IOS software under the hood.  The differences are in the interfaces (e.g., Web GUI, Studio 5000 integration).  The feature set of each product line is largely a function of the generation of IOS it was built on.

The very popular Stratix 5700 / IE2000 and Stratix 5400 / IE4000 lines do not appear in the reference architecture.  These generally work with most network management tools, but not necessarily the latest software-defined networking tools.  These are more like the older Catalyst 2900 and 3700.  These run the older IOS (pre IOS-XE).

It's also worth mentioning that you may not necessarily need native Cybervision compatibility at the access layer in every machine panel.  You may get away with deploying through a Catalyst 9300 or VM further up in your distribution and core layers.  Industrial networks, at least in discrete manufacturing, tend to scale out at the distribution layer.  They have many, smaller networks in the access layer.

TCP is the primary means of reliable data transfer in IP networks, which has served the Internet well since its inception and continues to be the optimal protocol for the majority of the communication. Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
First off, make sure you're using a true, commercial-grade internet circuit with a tier 1 carrier.  This will make the biggest difference.  This service is often marketed as Dedicated Internet Access (DIA).  It's typically characterized by having single mode fiber, symmetrical bandwidth, lower latency, service level agreement (SLA), and costs more than what anything that involves a cable modem.  

Internet circuits that are marketed to small businesses are typically the same "best-effort" networks used for residential customers.  They just have a separate sales and support channels.  Operationally, it's the same.  This is usually not a dedicated internet access product.

In an ideal world, a site should have at least two dedicated internet circuits from different carriers.  That is, carriers that are diverse physically and how they route your traffic.  Otherwise, it's not helpful to have a second carrier that is merely handing off to your first carrier up stream.  From there, you can creating routing policies to choose the optimal path.  Or, you can even multi-home the circuits with BGP routing. 

You could also explore SD-WAN.  This involves deploying SD-WAN nodes at your site and in your AWS tenant.  These use "overlay" protocols (typically IPSec tunnels) across the various connections available between your site and AWS.  Based on the policies you define, it will optimize traffic across the connections.  It will actively use all connections and seamlessly remediate anytime performance degrades with the underlying transport.

If you have exceptional challenges, you could contract your carrier to setup a dedicated WAN circuit (e.g., MPLS, Carrier Ethernet) between your site and AWS.  It's costly.  It also requires an AWS service to terminate the connections.  Some partners will terminate at the edge for a lower cost.

Author: akoscs
Content:
DHCP on an IP based OT network is OK, some will be static some can be dynamic. In many cases I find this helpful. For added security you can whitelist MAC addresses (firewall, not DHCP function), I used whitelisted USB-ETH convertors in some cases, only those could be used to program stuff on the network, not as rigid as only one engineering PC, not as permissive as any laptop. 

Also there might be networks which have no IP layer, if you have motion control, Profinet, sercos or EtherCAT should not be mixed with IP networks.

Author: mparris
Content:
DHCP is alright for devices acting as clients that are connecting to servers with static IPs to get data.

Using DHCP for servers could lead to IP Addresses changing, which will make all the users mad when they have to change their setups.

Another route is to use DHCP with static reservations, where you can bind a Mac address to a fixed IP. the device still uses DHCP to get an address, but the assignment is deterministic.

Another option is DHCP assignments to switch ports, where a device connected to a specific port will get the same address every time. This helps speed up replacement of devices that support DHCP.

then there is also DHCP with dynamic update to a DNS server, where the device has a static hostname and advertises it to the DHCP server, then the DHCP server feeds it to a DNS server, so devices that support connecting via FQDN can reference the hostname without caring about what the IP address is

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
I came across some switches that a cloud provider uses, and learned that their switches dont have any persistent storage, and are remotely configured from a host server. 

While this makes sense (more flexibility to change configs centrally based on networking needs), what it also means is that there is no disk drive in the switch, and its settings get reset everytime it power cycles. Using a product like this - outside of its intended use case is a bad idea....

Its opened my eyes up to the major trends in the internet, data centers, etc. With MaaS being more common, treating end devices as fully programmable nodes that can change behavior based on upstream demands....sounds very I4.0 like - but i have never seen an automation controls/network product that (for example) - could convert from linux to windows without major inconveniences and manual work.

I wonder if networking concepts like this will ever make its way to industrial equipment.....im seeing NIC and network technology in general gain more influence in data center control structures

Author: zeratall
Content:
Was anyone else surprised by Walker's overview of their DTMA for Networks? If you missed it, here's the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nb6GlTmER44, if you have' t I would highly recommend, its an excellent video on DTMA, Platforms, and DT for MFG in general. 

That being said, I was surprised on the network section when Walker was going over their DTMA. Analyzing just coverage seemed a bit shallow to me. In my view, the ability for Network Operations to facilitate rapid iteration is absolutely critical for digital transformation and assessing digital maturity. When I conduct my own DTMA assessments for manufacturing sites, I make it a point to include a thorough evaluation of Network Operations activities. The reason is that while most of our sites may have 100% coverage, the real differentiator lies in how agile and responsive the Network Operations teams are.

Some sites are leveraging modern network technology that allows us to make network changes in minutes, which is essential for supporting the fast-paced, iterative nature of digital initiatives. On the other hand, some sites are still using outdated technology and have understaffed Network Operations teams, where even minor changes become a cumbersome and time-consuming process. This disparity can significantly impact the overall digital maturity of a site and its ability to adapt to new digital tools and processes.

In my opinion, for a DTMA to truly reflect the digital readiness of an organization, it should encompass not only network coverage but also the agility and capability of Network Operations to drive and support rapid transformation. I'm curious if anyone else had similar thoughts. I really appreciate Walker's DTMA, but the network section didn't fully resonate with me.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: VLANS are VERY GOOD.  We use them the same.  They also provide segmentation, so you can control access to only those that need it.  We've even got a VLAN that is inaccessible by anyone inside our network. It allows the devices on it to talk to an Azure endpoint (outbound connections only),  The devices on it belong to a 3rd party, so there's no need for any of our folks to be able to access that VLAN, nor for any of the devices to talk to anything else on our network.  So being able to drop them all into a VLAN makes it simple.

Author: ted.garrison

That way when the OEM tech is in doing service, they're constrained to only their machines, which further reduces risk.  We've got some of that already, but it's not standardized yet.

Author: zeratall
Content: VLANs aren't inherently bad, but issues arise when dealing with large, complex, multi-layered (subnetted) networks. In these environments, making a single network change often requires modifications across multiple layers, which not only slows down Network Operations but also increases the risk of introducing errors (like typos) when updating configurations. This is why Software-Defined Networking (SDN) solutions the implement "Intent Based Networking", such as Cisco SDA, are becoming increasingly attractive. They can significantly reduce the time it takes to implement network changes and improve overall agility

Author: zeratall
Content: VLANs are not bad, they are just becoming the legacy way of doing networks that can slow down Network Ops, which is an area a lot of these newer network technology stacks are trying to solve. Which is especially important when you start to look at the future demand to connect more machines to the network as digital maturity increases.

Author: mparris
Content:
Consider a house as an analogy. 

VLANs are like rooms... All people in the room may freely talk.

Hallways are routes, and people in rooms connected by hallways may talk.

Doors in the rooms are firewalls, allowing selection of who may enter one or more VLANs.

It's good to have VLANs and routes between VLANs, and firewalls to control traffic between VLANs.

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
> a particular interface of a switch that is configured as access have only one VLAN
It doesn't have to be limited to only one.  We're doing this with TSN: a disciplined endpoint talks to its PLC (in deterministic real time) over one VLAN, and sends IIoT data over another using "best effort" prioritisation.  More VLANs can be added as required.  The endpoint can proactively throttle throughput as required before packets even go onto the wire.
Of course, undisciplined endpoints are stuck with whatever the router gives them, and can't actively use multiple VLANs.

Author: mparris

Content: Yes, exactly that.  We're talking about the physical endpoint with the MAC address (and not the IP endpoints used by the VLANs themselves).

Content: I am going through the 3-Day UNS Workship from Sep...there was an interesting discussion about using NAT to satisfy the "connect" - but I never heard IOT Edge Gateways brought up as part of the conversation. Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
There‚Äôs a few ways to approach this. I agree that throwing edge hardware to handle protocol and network translations has scalability issues. It's a lot to procure, install, and support. On the other hand, if connecting for the first time, it‚Äôs not realistic to assume every field network (e.g., machine builders delivered with 192.168.1.1/28 on every asset) can easily be uplinked to one flat network. This will have to be resolved somehow - either on the devices or on the network.

I would look into figuring out an access and distribution network strategy. You could do your NATS here rather on disparate edge devices. At a minimum, there should be managed layer 3 switches to segment the field networks.

Personally, I think plants should take control of their field networks and get accustomed to managing addresses. I understand it‚Äôs not always possible or that it‚Äôs a challenge, but there is also a ‚Äúcost‚Äù to leaving everything as-is.  Planning and cleaning up an address space creates more network awareness and mitigates risks. It‚Äôs healthy. It‚Äôs also way less confusing for technicians not accustomed to having a ‚Äúpublic‚Äù and ‚Äúprivate‚Äù addresses for the same device.

In a discrete manufacturing environment, I would recommend segmenting every asset or cell with local field communications into its own /24. Make sure a gateway address is defined on the devices. Setup inter VLAN routes if different cells need to communicate beyond their local network. These can be used to drive security policies. For acquiring data, use a a software based protocol gateway (e.g., kepware). The network will route to the devices to connect. This can be done on managed switches and remotely administered.

TL;DR: Don‚Äôt use a fleet of edge devices. Use big 48+ port rack unit switches at the distribution frames instead. Plan and segment the network. Connect to the devices natively and make your ‚Äúedge‚Äù a software node above this.

Author: ajcamm_88960
Content: Thanks for the thoughts here. We are actually discussing this exact route - the idea is that the local expertise doesn't exist, so land the devices and perform NAT at the IDF. However, that still requires corporate IT support. Where, local edge devices would not but it turns into 'NAT at the Edge' vs 'Edge Gateway'. I should clarify that in this case we wouldn't be using the Gateways to translate protocols, but rather just to "connect" and get the data, land it via OPC at the Edge OPC Server (Kepware).

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Great post, I think the most important thing there is you have to have a plan, and I have gone through the "fun" of migrating all the IP addresses in a few plants over ,
But are you really looking at connecting all the OT equipment back to 48port switches?  I find two big problems with that approach , the first is it is much harder to trouble shoot OT comms issues, and at a some point in the future, someone will want to move the equipment.

@Andrew Camm does having a NAT device at the edge, or even in a switch room really need less expertise to manage, than just changing the IP addresses as they arrive? Or giving the Vendor a set of IP addresses as they are building?

The best middle of the road approach I have recommended, is to have an 8 or 16 port Level 3 Managed switch in a panel for the Production Network and a second dumb switch for the local Machine network. 
Have 2 IP addresses for a PLC , one is connected to the Production network via the managed switch, the other connected to machine level equipment, mainly RIO.
Some equipment can be on either network like flow meters, drives etc but you can either connect them to the machine network originally, or connect them to the managed switch.
But all of the equipment in the machine has a unique IP address for that Plant, and if you want to connect form the Production layer( SCADA or IIoT platform) you can move equipment from one switch to the other.

you can then in the future if needed connect the second dumb switch into the managed switch, or upgrade it to a managed switch and have fancy stuff like rings/MRP etc

Anyone I have worked with who had had the NAT device at each machine, tend to rip it out and migrate over all the equipment to unique IP addresses after a year of digital transformation.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
To clarify, I was referring to an access/distribution layer between field networks and applications. Communicating within a field network is generally best done locally. It makes a lot of sense to keep dependencies within an asset or cell.

The approach you mentioned involving an "8 or 16 L3 managed switch in a panel" is more or less what I was describing, but with rack and structured cabling infrastructure. I would add that, if deploying in machine panel is not a requirement, rack switches usually have better reliability features, higher port density, and are more available/economical. Being able to "stack" in high availability configs and hot-swap power supplies is very useful, for example.

I'm not following the point on troubleshooting. Could you elaborate? In my experience, the amount of observability tools that can consume NetFlow, J-Flow, IPSIX, etc is extensive compared to what's available for most (not all) industrial switches. The alerts and reporting can save so much time for everyone involved.

I definitely agree on the NAT point. It tends to rack up even more technical debt.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I am thinking of a machine which is stopped and maintenance call out to the panel, and are looking at the PLC and Drives.

I have seen proposals where every field device that connects using an ethenet cable would be wired back to a Rack.
So you had a PLC communicating with a VFD in the same Panel, communicating Via a Rack 50m away.

I didn't think you would propose that, but it reads a bit that way.

instead of a 0.5m local cable connection that a maintenance technician could pull out . and make sure the correct lights were flashing.
I am think here where the comms are Control Level, and especially if the components are close to each other, a local connection is the way to go.

I also do like not having lots of OT devices( Profibus in my experience) on the same network as Production Level VM's.
Stuff like backups and system scans and all the other rightly essential IT stuff, messes with the comms layer.

Missed quality checks, missed starts for new work orders, or even issues with Safety communications, out of sequence packets and the like shutting down. 
And they always seam to happen at the same time every day, and every 8 hours.

or my personal favourite, where an Old Siemens TI PLC would crash at 12:05 on a Friday, and the electricians would head up pull out the comms car and put it back in. 
Big site backup was scheduled and the network segregations and QOS was not as it should have been.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Much depends on the machine and its protocol. What we observe is that loading a program from a machine often requires orchestration of various actions. The first step is to ensure that the machine is ready to receive a new program. Then the program has to be sent to it, often using protocols such as FTP, SMB, etc., and then services have to be called up again to confirm that the machine can work again. It is therefore necessary to have service orchestration tools (Node-RED), tools to exploit machine methods such as Focas APIs, and finally a solution for moving binary files. To my surprise, NodeRed is very relevant for these tasks, we also use Highbyte to bridge the gap between Cloud and Edge, and finally we are increasingly using the versioning capabilities of PLM to store G-Code.
